intro: Apargia fasciculata, commonly known as the clustered false foxglove, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the family Orobanchaceae, which includes many parasitic and semi-parasitic species. The plant is characterized by its tall, slender stems and clusters of small, tubular, pink to purple flowers. Its leaves are opposite and lance-shaped, often with a slightly hairy texture. Apargia fasciculata typically grows in moist, shaded habitats such as woodlands and along stream banks.
